title: Carnival of Monsters
dialogue_triumphs: Orum on Functionaries: 'Give them a hygiene chamber, they store fossil fuel in it!'
goofs: In episode one the sound of a pencil dropping and rolling across the studio floor can be heard.
The Doctor is told that Vorg is in charge of the scope in episode four, but later he asks whether Vorg is in charge.
The Drashigs are introduced twice in episode two.
Vorg claims he can't control the Drashigs (they're not intelligent) but he can control the plesiosaur.
The 1926 calendar is wrong (the date structure is that of 1925).
When questioned by Jo about the banning of the miniscopes, the Doctor suggests that this one was missed, completely forgetting that they could be in a time before the ban.

continuity_notes.name: Miniscope
continuity_notes.description: A device that miniaturizes and contains living beings for entertainment purposes. Banned by the Time Lords.
continuity_notes.origin: Created by the Eternity Perpetual Company
continuity_notes.current_status: In use by Vorg, won at the Great Wallarian Exhibition

continuity_notes.name: Metebelis 3
continuity_notes.description: The famous blue planet of the Acteon group
continuity_notes.current_status: Mentioned for the first time in this episode

continuity_notes.name: SS Bernice
continuity_notes.description: A ship that disappeared in the Indian Ocean in 1926, now trapped in a time loop within the miniscope

continuity_notes.name: Drashigs
continuity_notes.description: Terrifying carnivores from a swampy satellite of Grundle

technobabble: The miniscope's shell is made of molecular-bonded disillion
The sonic screwdriver is used to explode marsh gas
roots: J. B. Priestley, especially 'Time and the Conways'

locations.name: Inter Minor
locations.description: Home planet of the bureaucratic Minorians
locations.current_status: Setting for part of the episode

locations.name: Miniscope
locations.description: Interior of the device containing miniaturized beings
locations.origin: Created by the Eternity Perpetual Company
locations.current_status: Setting for part of the episode

future_history: The story is said to take place '1000 years after the Great Space Plague'
untold_adventures: The Doctor took boxing lessons from John L. Sullivan (American heavyweight champion, 1892)
additional_notes: This is the only Doctor Who story to mention Fred Astaire (despite being set seven years before Astaire became well known).
bottom_line: 'Carnival of Monsters' is a parody of television and its viewers. It retains the cheeky power of its initial broadcast.
